Award.AwardTitle: BD Spokes: SPOKE: WEST: Collaborative: MetroInsight: Knowledge Discovery and Real-Time Interventions from Sensory Data Flows in Urban Spaces

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The MetroInsight project is building an end to end system for knowledge discovery from real-time data streams collected through a variety of sensors, data collection and aggregation methods. These data streams are highly dimensional with multiple sensors observing same or similar phenomena over multiple sensory spectrums and scales. These are also sometimes real-time and/or have strong timing relationships that is necessary to support metropolitan infrastructure through effective analytics and policy support. The project brings together a diverse number of partners utilities, universities, companies and cities with the ability to contribute novel tools and urban sensor data and to translate knowledge into actions. MetroInsight's unique combination of tools, data and partnerships, in part with the MetroLab Network , makes it well poised to set an example for the MetroLab programs across the nation as well as the rest of the municipal governments. The project will explore connections between multimodal datasets and urban infrastructure management to build a practical system consisting of integrated tools, as well as training a new generation of metropolitan workforce. As part of an ambitious plan for community building and workforce development, the project includes creation of new learning modules, certification programs on energy and sustainability, an online courses on sensor data analytics and new capstone projects in a new Data Science master's degree program.

To achieve project goals, MetroInsight is building infrastructure for managing data, networks and processing that will support design of new algorithms and tools in the project. Specifically, the project is developing algorithms to transform multimodal urban data to a lower dimensional data that reflects underlying physical and social phenomena. These low dimensional data may consist of population level data suitable for dynamic processing to support real time monitoring and visualization by cityscale operators of various lifelines from transportation, communications to emergency response. To address technical challenges in complex and subtle spatiotemporal dynamics of interdependent urban networks, MetroInsight will develop metadata methods and tools that support discovery of operational interdependencies, quantification of uncertainties for decision support and to provide assurances related to integrity and security of data, compliance related to ethical and legal privacy expectations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The MetroInsight project built an end-to-end system for organization and exploration of metropolitan scale cyber-coupled systems using highly-dimensional sensor time-series and real-time data streams. This is a critical component of the emerging cyber-infrastructure in support of the metropolitan infrastructure through effective data analytics, workforce development, and policy support over the long term. To achieve this goal, the project required both technical as well as personnel engagement across multiple civic agencies and systems.

The UC San Diego team coordinated the project and collaborations with project advisors and community partners, as well as the federated data collection and management services and the metadata on the federated datasets on quality and provenance of information. Additionally, the project demonstrated the viability of implementing analytical methods and models, scalability of such models using analytical workflow management tools, and cyberinfrastructure development related to these goals.

Towards the high-level goal of creating a convergence framework for public/private/government data, the project collected and organized data to build programmatic access to heterogeneous urban data through unified application programming interfaces for spatiotemporal data search and access in a scalable, open and policy-driven way. The services were shared through Citadel, a data hub for city-scale data services. The services were demonstrated on AWS through a grant from Amazon Web Services. Additionally, the team made progress towards reference implementation and release of the Brick metadata schema (http://brickschema.org) as a concrete example of how data sets emerging from commercial buildings can be organized systematically through advances in metadata methods. The Brick Schema as now been adopted by a non-profit consortium of companies and academic partners to promote its adoption and use as an industry standard.  

The project also explored coding and the use of analytical methods used among academic and civic agencies via multiple student projects as targeted case studies. These case studies ranged from predictive traffic data analysis and event-aware  (e.g., hazards, sports competitions, etc) dynamic data-driven route optimization and analysis of sequential data streams in conjunction with traffic datasets to housing value analysis for San Diego.  

The early indications of adoption of results from the case studies and developed data sets are promising based on our interactions with a range of community collaborators and partners including the City of San Diego, many fire departments and the UC San Diego facilities. The project team also worked with the local industry and start-up organizations, e.g., Tech San Diego, CyberTech SD, CleanTech SD, and Scale SD, to make sure the project findings are communicated as a part of the local development ecosystem. This work continues as our follow up activities as a notable broader impact of the MetroInsight project.
